description: From French disque, from Latin discus, from Ancient Greek δίσκος (dískos, “disk, quoit, platter”). Doublet of dais, desk, discus, dish, disk, and diskos.

entries.meaning: A thin, flat, circular plate or similar object.
examples: A coin is a disc of metal.
Venus's disc cut off light from the Sun.
Turn the disc over, after it has finished.

entries.meaning: (botany) The flat surface of an organ, as a leaf, any flat, round growth.
(disc sports) Ellipsis of flying disc.; Synonym of frisbee; generic name for the trademark Frisbee;

verbs.description: disc (third-person singular simple present discs, present participle discing, simple past and past participle disced)

entries.meaning: (agriculture) To harrow with a disc harrow.
(aviation, of a propeller) To move towards, or operate at, zero blade pitch, orienting the propeller blades face-on to the oncoming airflow and maximising the drag generated by the propeller.
examples: In the air, the asymmetric drag generated by a discing propeller can result in loss of control of the airplane.
